    Benzyl Phenylsemicarbazides: A Chemistry-Driven Approach Leading to G Protein-Biased Dopamine D4 Receptor Agonists with High Subtype Selectivity

    • Anna S. Pirzer
      Anna S. Pirzer
      Department of Chemistry and Pharmacy, Medicinal Chemistry, Friedrich-Alexander-Universität Erlangen-Nürnberg, Nikolaus-Fiebiger-Str. 10, 91058 Erlangen, Germany

    SUBJECTS:
    • Amines,
    • Ligands,
    • Pharmaceuticals,
    • Selectivity,
    • Receptors
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Many subtype-selective dopamine receptor ligands developed for the D2–D4 family incorporate a 1-arylpiperazine-derived primary recognition motif, which is connected to a lipophilic moiety occupying an extended binding pocket (EBP) of the receptor via an aliphatic linker of variable lengths. The evaluation of a novel group of dopamine receptor ligands now showed that highly subtype-selective ligands [up to Ki(D4.4) = 0.25 nM, D2L/D4.4 = 320, D3/D4.4 = 710 for APH199 (17)] can be obtained by choosing a relatively large and conformationally flexible 1-benzyl-1-phenylsemicarbazide substructure to fill the EBP. The novel chemotype APH199 (17) was found to act as a full agonist at the D4 receptor showing significant bias toward G protein activation over β-arrestin recruitment in comparison to quinpirole.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Dopamine is one of the most prevalent catecholamines in the human brain and affects many processes in the central nervous system.(1) A variety of disorders can be associated to imbalances in the dopamine neurotransmitter system and, thus, dopamine receptors play a crucial role as drug targets in medicinal chemistry. The family of the human dopamine receptors refers to the rhodopsin like G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) and can be divided into the D1-like subgroup, consisting of the D1 and the D5 receptor, and the D2-like subgroup, consisting of the D2, D3, and the D4 receptor, respectively.(2−4)
    When the D4 receptor was cloned and identified for the first time in 1991, and the preferential affinity of the atypical antipsychotic clozapine to this subtype was observed, efforts were undertaken to design and develop D4 receptor antagonists as new drugs for the treatment of schizophrenia.(5−7) A few years later in 1997, the initial enthusiasm to discover improved antipsychotic drugs with potentially less side effects faded because of a multicenter study revealing that the D4 selective receptor antagonist L-745870 was ineffective in the treatment of schizophrenia.(8)
    Nevertheless, subtype-selective D4 receptor ligands are still developed and investigated with the aim to provide better treatment options for addictive disorders associated with cocaine,(9,10) morphine,(11) amphetamine,(12−16) heroin,(12−16) and nicotine,(17) eating disorders like anorexia nervosa,(18−20) as well as attention deficit disorder.(21−24) Moreover, D4-selective compounds have been discussed as potential drugs with regard to erectile dysfunction(25−27) or cognitive deficits.(28) A very recent publication by Keck et al.(29) further highlights the importance of D4-subtype selective ligands (Ki up to 4.3 nM and >100-fold selectivity over D2-like receptors).
    The continuous interest in highly subtype and also functionally selective ligands for the D4 subtype becomes obvious from a very recent and so far unique approach, in which 138 million library molecules were docked against the D4 receptor.(30) From 589 selected hits, 549 molecules were successfully synthesized, and further optimization of the docking hit ZINC621433143 in terms of stereochemistry led to the full agonist ZINC621433144 (Ki = 180 pM).(30) This compound did not only show high subtype selectivity toward D4, but was also functionally selective with a 17-fold preference toward Gi signaling versus β-arrestin recruitment, compared to the classic agonist quinpirole.
    Previous studies showed that D4 selectivity can be achieved by connecting a 1-arylpiperazine recognition element, which represents a substitute for the endogenous dopamine, to a lipophilic appendage via a short methylene (C1) linker unit.(31−34) This structure-subtype selectivity relationship is nicely supported by the D4 receptor antagonists 1a and 1b developed by Kulagowski,(35) displaying sub-nanomolar affinity and high subtype selectivity (Figure 1).
    Structurally related antagonists of 1a and 1b, in which the 7-azaindole substructure was replaced by an indole, a 7a-azaindole (pyrazolopyridine) or an azulene unit, showed similar D4 binding affinity and subtype selectivity, thereby strengthening the suitability of the overall structural design.(36−38) The D4-selective agonist PD168077 (2) developed by Glase(39) and the docking hit ZINC621433144 (3)(29) are no longer in accordance with the structural requirements mentioned above. The length of the linker units has been discussed earlier,(38,40−45) and elongated alkyl chains can be found in the D4-selective ligands 4 and 5, recently developed by Sampson(46) and Wang.(47) The new chemotype 5, in which the quinolone moiety acts as a primary recognition motif and the phenoxy unit represents the lipophilic appendage, was developed using data from the previously determined D4 crystal structure (co-crystallized with nemonapride) in combination with virtual screening. Taking the D4 crystal structure as a basis, the detailed docking results from the study by Wang(47) clearly support that new chemotypes with longer alkyl linker units can be well tolerated by the D4 subtype.
    Seeking for a new chemotype that may confer atypical biological effects such as ligand bias, we found it challenging to investigate if the combination of an elongated linker unit and a comparably large, but flexible lipophilic appendage—such as in the general structure 6—might also be a suitable approach to induce strong D4 subtype selectivity. Encouraged by the remarkable functional selectivity of the atypical chemotype ZINC621433144 (3)(29) (17-fold preference toward Gi vs β-arrestin), we thought to investigate the effect of our newly developed chemotype on the downstream signaling pathways, thereby aiming to get further insights into the structural determinants for functional selectivity, which are so far poorly understood.
    Using a chemistry-based approach, and exploiting a newly developed reductive alkylation method,(48) we now show that the extended binding pocket (EBP) of the dopamine D4 receptor can indeed tolerate a sterically demanding benzyl phenylsemicarbazide substructure, a crucial element of our newly developed ligands of type 6. Our study comprises 36 novel ligands, which we evaluated for their affinity to the dopamine D4.4 receptor and their subtype selectivity in comparison to the other D2-like receptors, D2L, D2S, and D3. The most promising ligands were further studied in functional assays and characterized for their selectivity over a small set of related GPCRs. Modeling studies finally pointed to new key interactions, thereby showing that the EBP in the dopamine D2–4 receptor family can be a valuable starting point for future developments with regard to ligands displaying both high subtype and functional selectivity.

    Results

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Synthesis

    The synthesis of the target compounds started from the commercially available 1-arylpiperazines 7a–e which were alkylated with N-phthalyl-protected bromoalkyl amines 8a–c (Scheme 1). Deprotection with hydrazine provided the free amines 10a–i, which were subsequently coupled to various phenylazocarboxylic acid tert-butyl esters 11a–f to give the azocarboxamides 12a–n. The final reductive N-alkylation of 12a–n with benzyl and allyl bromides 13a–i was carried out according to a protocol recently developed in our group,(48) thereby completing the straightforward synthesis of the semicarbazide target compounds 14–47. Remarkably, the presence of zinc changes the selectivity of the final alkylation, as one would otherwise expect a selective functionalization at the tertiary aliphatic amino group in the piperazine subunit of 12. However, and especially for the lower yielding alkylation reactions, we can currently not exclude that alkylation at the tertiary aliphatic amine also occurs to a significant extent.
    Notably, compounds that include comparably substituted semicarbazide substructures as the D4 ligands prepared within this work, have, among others, previously appeared in studies focusing on MAP kinase inhibitors,(49) inhibitors of integrin binding,(50) and blood coagulation.(51) Compared to semicarbazides bearing only one substituent on the β-nitrogen atom of the hydrazine subunit, the β,β-disubstituted derivatives presented herein cannot be directly oxidized to their corresponding azo compounds and do thus show a high chemical stability, which was also observed during their preparation. No decomposition occurred even after storing the semicarbazide ligands in solution and at ambient temperature over several weeks.

    Ligand Binding

    Radioligand competition binding assays were performed to determine binding affinities and the selectivity profiles of 12c(52) and the new dopamine receptor ligands 12a, 12b and 14–47 in comparison to the previously described compounds L-745870 (1a) and PD168077 (2). The binding data were generated by measuring the ligands’ ability to compete with [3H]spiperone for the in-house available cloned human dopamine receptor subtypes D2L, D2S, D3, and D4.4 stably expressed in CHO cells (Tables 1–5). As the Ki values were derived from binding experiments that have been analyzed as monophasic curves, the selectivity profiles may be inferred when applying different binding conditions, that is, using an agonist radioligand or varying the ratio between receptor and G protein in the membranes.
    Table 1. Radioligand Binding Data of Compounds 1a, 2, 12a–c, and 14–16 to the Subtypes of the Dopamine D2 Receptor Family
      Ki (nM ± SEM)aselectivityb
    compoundn=D2LD2SD3D4.4D2L/D4.4D2S/D4.4D3/D4.4
    L-745870 (1a) 47000 ± 520033000 ± 360065000 ± 120000.70 ± 0.04667 00047 00093 000
    PD168077 (2) 2300 ± 4701100 ± 1004700 ± 17002.3 ± 0.5610004802000
    12a1270 ± 26140 ± 26120 ± 3036 ± 5.47.53.93.3
    12b2110 ± 2151 ± 2.0140 ± 3720 ± 3.05.52.67.0
    12cc338 ± 4.634 ± 3.03.1 ± 0.3894 ± 130.400.360.033
    141100 ± 3571 ± 25700 ± 2209.0 ± 0.41117.978
    1526.6 ± 1.54.3 ± 0.7625 ± 6.00.55 ± 0.087127.845
    163160 ± 2194 ± 1976 ± 5.24.4 ± 0.95362117

    Values are reported as mean (nM ± SEM) of three to five individual experiments each done in triplicate and analyzing the data applying a monophasic curve fitting.

    b

    Subtype selectivity for D4.4 over D2L, D2S, or D3 (=Dx) was determined by calculating the ratio of Ki DX/Ki D4.4.

    c

    The Ki values determined for 12c are similar to those previously reported in ref (52).

    Table 5. Binding Data of Compounds 40 and 45–47
      Ki (nM ± SEM)aselectivityb
    compoundn=D2LD2SD3D4.4D2L/D4.4D2S/D4.4D3/D4.4
    402730 ± 100520 ± 671500 ± 31014 ± 7.05237110

    b

    Subtype selectivity for D4.4 over D2L, D2S or D3 (=Dx) was determined by calculating the ratio of Ki DX/Ki D4.4.

    Already, the first series of semicarbazide ligands 14–16 revealed a modified binding profile compared to the azocarboxamide analogues 12a–c (Table 1). While the azocarboxamides 12a–c were found to be at least roughly in agreement with the established rule that short linker units (12a, n = 1; 12b, n = 2) favor binding to the D4 subtype, while longer linkers such as C4 (12c, n = 3) shift the affinity toward D3,(52) the evaluation of the semicarbazides 14–16 revealed a remarkable preference for the D4 subtype independent of the linker length. As the best combination of affinity [Ki(D4.4) = 0.55 nM] and selectivity (D2L/D4.4 = 12, D3/D4.4 = 45) was determined for RLH676 (15) at a linker length of three carbon atoms (n = 2), the study was continued with this lead structure.
    Table 2 summarizes the results obtained upon variation of the substituents on the two aromatic moieties A and B of the benzyl phenylsemicarbazide unit. Compared to RLH676 (15), the subtype selectivity toward D4 could be strongly increased by shifting the fluorine atom from the 4-position of ring A to the 4-position of ring B, as in APH212 (18), and even slightly more by leaving both ring systems A and B unsubstituted, as in compound APH199 (17). Almost all other substitution patterns, as they are present in ligands 19–36, lead to a reduced D4 affinity and subtype selectivity. Regarding the trends in D4 binding affinity for the less potent ligands, most compounds show Ki values in a quite narrow range from 2 to 6 nM, indicating that a variety of substitution patterns is also quite well tolerated. Only unfavorable patterns such as 2,4-dichloro substitution on ring A (compounds 27 and 28) and/or 4-cyano and 3-methoxy substitution on ring B (compounds 23, 28, 35, and 36) resulted in Ki values higher than 10 nM. Notably, a good subtype selectivity (D2L/D4.4 = 55, D3/D4.4 = 140) was also observed for ligand 34, although this was not due to subnanomolar binding to D4 [Ki(D4.4) = 2.9 nM], but due to a much reduced affinity to the D2 and D3 subtypes.
    Having seen that the combination of an unsubstituted phenyl and an unsubstituted benzyl group on the semicarbazide, as present in compound APH199 (17), provides high affinity and subtype selectivity for the D4 receptor, we replaced the benzyl moiety by a smaller allyl or 2-methallyl unit to evaluate the effect of decreased size (Table 3). With compound 31 serving as a reference for this modification, it became apparent that allylation as well as 2-methallylation only lead to ligands 37 and 38 with significantly reduced D4 affinity and subtype selectivity. Thus, a certain size of the two units attached to the semicarbazide appears to be necessary to successfully differentiate between the D2–D4 subtypes.
    In the next stage, we turned to the variation of the recognition motif, which was so far represented by a 1-(2-methoxyphenyl)piperazine. Based on the highly potent and subtype-selective D4 receptor ligands reported so far (cf. Figure 1), the 2-methoxyphenyl unit was exchanged for a 4-chlorophenyl, 4-bromophenyl, or a pyrimidin-2-yl substructure. The results obtained in comparison to the so far most APH199 (17) and APH212 (18) are summarized in Table 4.
    For both series, either starting from the benzyl semicarbazide APH199 (17) or the 4-fluorobenzyl semicarbazide APH212 (18), these variations resulted in an at least 31-fold loss of D4 binding affinity for compounds 39–44 combined with a remarkable decrease of selectivity toward the other subtypes D2L, D2S, and D3. To answer the question whether the increased size of a 4-bromo or 4-iodo-substituted phenyl ring in the 1-arylpiperazine recognition motif could possibly be counterbalanced by a shorter linker length (cf. ligand 1b, Figure 1), we finally prepared the semicarbazides 45–47 (Table 5). In comparison to 4-bromo derivative 40 (Table 4), the exchange of the 4-bromo for a 4-iodo substituent as well as the shortening of linker length from three to two methylene units independently led to less binding affinity of the ligands 45–47 to the D4 subtype.
    The biological evaluation of the ligands 17 and 18, possessing the most favorable binding profile for the D4 subtype, toward receptors of the D1 family as well as other non-dopaminergic receptors demonstrated that significantly lower binding affinities (higher Ki values) are found for most other receptors (Table 6).
    Table 6. Binding Data of Compounds 17 and 18 to Receptors of the D1 Family As Well As Other Non-Dopaminergic Receptors
     Ki (nM ± SD)a
    compoundD1D5α1Aα2β1β2δ-OR
    APH199 (17)200 ± 120340 ± 211.7 ± 0.14400 ± 5713000 ± 35001800 ± 35010000 ± 7100
    APH212 (18)360 ± 991000 ± 911.6 ± 0.42860 ± 110>500004500 ± 42019000 ± 5600
     Ki (nM ± SD)a
    compoundκ-ORμ-OR5-HT1A5-HT2AM1M2M3
    APH199 (17)3900 ± 17002000 ± 85017 ± 2.165 ± 2.125000 ± 1400014000 ± 1100025000 ± 4900
    APH212 (18)4300 ± 16002300 ± 92034 ± 12130 ± 7.115000 ± 017000 ± 71037000 ± 9200
    a

    Values are reported as mean values in (nM ± SD) derived from two individual experiments each done in triplicate.

    The only exception was observed for the α1A subtype to which both ligands 17 and 18 showed a comparably strong binding with Ki values of 1.7 ± 0.14 and 1.6 ± 0.42 nM, respectively, which corresponds to selectivity ratios of 7.1 and 2.9 over the D4 subtype. Functional assays at the α1A receptor led to the observation that 17 and 18 both behave as neutral antagonists (see Supporting Information for dose–response curves). These assays were performed for Gαq mediated signaling (IP-One assay) and β-arrestin recruitment (PathHunter assay).
    Functional assays to determine agonistic or antagonistic properties at the D4 subtype were conducted for the most promising ligands RLH676 (15), APH199 (17), and APH212 (18) using quinpirole as a reference compound. The results summarized in Figure 2 and Table 7 show that all three compounds behave as almost full agonists with bias toward the G protein over the β-arrestin signaling pathway.
    Table 7. Key Data from Functional Assays Using Quinpirole As a Reference Compound
     IP-One-D4 + Gαqiaarrestin-D4-PKAb 
    compoundmaximal activation (% ± SEM)cEC50 (nM ± SEM)maximal activation (% ± SEM)cEC50 (nM ± SEM)dbias factor 10ΔΔlog(τ/KA)
    quinpirole1002.2 ± 0.210083 ± 0.71.0
    RLH676 (15)88 ± 41.8 ± 0.3922 ± 2340 ± 15026
    APH199 (17)89 ± 18.7 ± 4.216 ± 1250 ± 1504.9
    APH212 (18)86 ± 341 ± 1517 ± 1500 ± 1101.8
    a

    An IP-One assay with HEK293T cells transiently co-transfected with D4R and the G protein hybrid Gαqi was applied for the determination of G protein-mediated signaling of the test compounds at D4R.

    b

    Measuring of arrestin recruitment was performed using the PathHunter complementation assay with HEK293T cells stably expressing (EA)-β-arrestin and the transiently transfected D4R-PKA construct.

    c

    Maximum activation in % ± SEM relative to the reference quinpirole derived from six individual experiments each done in duplicate.

    d

    EC50 value ± SEM from six individual experiments each done in duplicate.

    Regarding signaling via the G protein pathway, a strong activation was determined for the three novel semicarbazides RLH676 (15), APH199 (17), and APH212 (18), which reach 86–89% of the maximum effect attainable by quinpirole. The functional assay on β-arrestin recruitment, in contrast, revealed that 15, 17, and 18 do by far not reach the same level of activation as quinpirole and act as weak partial agonists (16–22% relative to quinpirole). In the presence of an agonist (300 nM of quinpirole), 15, 17, and 18 dose-dependently inhibit this effect with the best potency observed for 15 (for 15: IC50 = 49 ± 19 nM, for 17: IC50 = 450 ± 140 nM, for 18: IC50 = 620 ± 220 nM) and displayed a partial antagonist effect (Figure 2B).
    The fact that the control compound quinpirole shows an approximately 38-fold higher affinity for the G protein assay versus the β-arrestin assay, with EC50 values of 2.2 versus 83 nM, is most likely due to an amplification of the G protein response by the spare receptor phenomenon,(53) rather than that the control compound quinpirole exhibits a significant bias. Comparing the EC50 (affinity) ratio of 38 [EC50(β-arr.)/EC50(Gi)] for quinpirole with the ratios calculated in the same way for the semicarbazides 15, 17, and 18, which leads to values of 189, 29, and 12, respectively, shows that only RLH676 (15) displays an affinity- and efficacy-wise bias toward the G protein. For APH199 (17) and APH212 (18), a lower affinity-wise bias (EC50 ratios of 29 and 12 vs 38 for quinpirole) was determined, so that the overall bias seen in the signaling of 17 and 18 is primarily driven by a loss of efficacy at stimulating the β-arrestin pathway—not a loss of affinity. These considerations are supported by the bias factors calculated for 15, 17, and 18 according to the operational model by Black and Leff,(54) thereby following recently published procedures.(55,56) From these calculations, a comparably high bias factor of 26 was obtained for RLH676 (15), while lower values of 4.9 and 1.8 were determined for 17 and 18, respectively. From literature, functional data are available for the recently developed D4-selective ligand 621433134 (3) (Figure 1), which was also evaluated using quinpirole as reference, and for which a G protein over β-arrestin bias factor of 17 was calculated.(30)

    Studies on Metabolic Stability

    The metabolic stability of semicarbazide APH199 (17) was studied using male rat liver microsomes and imipramine under previously established conditions.(57,58) The reliability of the assay could be confirmed, as product patterns similar to those reported for imipramine in literature were obtained after comparable incubation times with N-demethylation and hydroxylation occurring as main metabolic pathways.(57) The results obtained for APH199 (17) in comparison with imipramine are summarized in Figure 3.
    As shown in Figure 3, APH199 (17) was found to be more stable than imipramine under the assay conditions, whereas imipramine is typically classified as a moderately stable positive control for phase I metabolism.(57,58) After 120 min incubation time, analysis of the reaction mixture by LC–ESI–MS showed approximately 50% hydroxylation of 17 (detected as [M + O + H]+: m/z = 490), approximately 20% of O-demethylated 17 (detected as [M – CH2 + H]+: m/z = 460), approximately 20% of N-debenzylated 17 (detected as [M – C7H6 + H]+: m/z = 384), and approximately 10% of unchanged APH199 (17) (detected as [M + H]+: m/z = 474). These results suggest that 17 should possess sufficient metabolic stability to be considered for in vivo testing in the future. Furthermore, no warnings in the PAINS screening were obtained for the metabolites of APH199 (17) resulting from O-demethylation and N-debenzylation. The hydroxylated metabolite could not be screened because the actual position of the hydroxy group is so far unknown.

    Docking

    Docking studies(59−61) were performed to get insights into the binding poses of the novel semicarbazide ligands, especially the possible interactions in the EBP. Moreover, explanations for subtype selectivity can be derived. Advantageously, crystal structures are available for the dopamine receptor subtypes D2, D3, and D4, which were recently co-crystalized with the antagonists risperidone,(62) eticlopride,(63) and nemonapride,(47) respectively.
    The EBP (Figure 4, left) in the D4 subtype is mainly surrounded by amino acids bearing nonpolar side chains with the exception of Arg186, whereas the hydrophilic guanidine moiety is however not orientated toward the lipophilic benzyl unit of the ligand 17. From the comparably long distance between the benzyl unit of 17 and the guanidine side chain of Arg186, which is around 5.2 Å, only a very weak cation-aryl interaction could possibly occur.(64) Lipophilic amino acids that are in vicinity to the phenyl moiety of APH199 (17) are Val87, Leu90, Phe91, and Leu111 (highlighted in pink). A lipophilic residue, which is closely located to the benzyl moiety on the semicarbazide is the side chain of Val184, and Trp101 might act as a further boundary element for the EBP.
    Key interactions of the polar residues of ligand 17 are shown in the center of Figure 4. The protonated tertiary aliphatic amine forms a salt bridge with Asp115 from TM3 and the carbonyl unit of the semicarbazide is engaged in a hydrogen bond with Thr434 from TM7. Because of these two anchor groups, we assume that the C3 alkyl spacer present in 17 provides the necessary flexibility so that both interactions to Asp115 and Thr434 can effectively occur, while the large lipophilic benzyl phenylsemicarbazide of 17 is at the same time correctly directed into the EBP. The fixation of the 3-methoxyphenyl unit of the 1-arylpiperazine recognition element by Val116 from TM3 and Phe411 from TM6 has earlier been observed for the corresponding recognition element of nemonapride in its co-crystal with the D4 receptor.(47) Insights into the effects that are responsible for the subtype selectivity of the D4 ligand 17 over the subtypes D2 and D3 are given in Figure 5.
    From the computational results depicted in Figure 5, one can conclude that the EBP is likely to play a key role in the context of subtype selectivity of the novel semicarbazide ligands. As nicely shown by Wang,(62) an EBP is available in all three subtypes D2, D3, and D4, but its orientation within the overall seven transmembrane structure changes significantly. An important amino acid, which leads to this reorientation, is Leu111 from TM3 in D4, which is exchanged for a much bulkier Phe110 in the D2 subtype and for a Phe106 in the D3 subtype (Figure 5, right). Although the EBP of the D2 and D3 subtypes is on the other hand larger at the original position of Phe91 in D4, as this amino acid is replaced by either Val91 in D2 or Val86 in D3, the semicarbazide ligand 17 appears to be unable to follow this reorientation as the polar key interactions shown in Figure 4 (center) only allow a favorable placement of the bulky benzyl phenylsemicarbazide unit in the EBP of the D4 subtype. Therefore, if no simple reorientation is possible for ligand 17 in the other subtypes, the phenyl moiety on the semicarbazide is likely to lead to a significant steric clash with Phe110 in D2 and Phe106 in D3, thereby explaining the observed subtype selectivity. Moreover, the importance of the key interactions (Figure 4, center) also provides an explanation for the reduced influence of the chain length connecting the recognition element and the lipophilic appendage (cf. Figure 1) in the semicarbazide ligands. As shown in Table 1, all three semicarbazides 14–16 displayed a remarkable selectivity toward D4, although the length of the alkyl linker was varied from two to three, and finally four methylene units. In contrast, the key interactions of the novel semicarbazide ligands with Asp115 and Thr434 (Figure 4, center) are significantly disturbed when a more bulky nitrile group is placed on the benzyl moiety of the semicarbazide, such as in ligand 23, because either the salt bridge to Asp115 can then no longer be formed or the size of the EBP in the D4 subtype will become insufficient to host the enlarged benzyl phenylsemicarbazide.
    Finally, the docking study was extended to the known D4 selective ligands 1b and 9-6-24 (5) (Figure 6). Because these computational experiments led to a similar docking pose for 9-6-24 (5) as previously determined by Wang et al.,(47) the obtained results can serve as a control for the reliability of our docking studies.
    As shown in Figure 6, both ligands 1b and 5 only partially occupy the EBP available in the D4 subtype, whereas the lipophilic 4-iodophenyl group of ligand 1b points to TM6 and TM7 (Figure 6, left) and the phenoxy unit in ligand 5 is oriented toward TM2 and TM3 (Figure 6, right). Notably, the alternative orientation of ligand 1b, in which the 4-iodophenylpiperazine acts as a recognition element and the 7-azaindole moiety occupies the EBP, would lead to a much larger distance between the protonated piperazine nitrogen and Asp115 (5.7 Å) and can thus be considered as much less likely (see Supporting Information). All three ligands 1b, 9-6-24 (5), and APH199 (17) show a similar key interaction of their protonated amine to Asp115 from TM3 (Figures 6 and 4, center), but only 5 and 17 display a second polar interaction of their lipophilic appendages directed to the EBP. Whereas this second polar interaction of the semicarbazide APH199 (17) is an intermolecular one (semicarbazide carbonyl to Thr434 in the D4 subtype, Figure 4, center) the favorable placement of the phenoxy unit of 9-6-24 (5) in the EBP is secured by an intramolecular interaction of the ether oxygen atom to a hydrogen atom on the protonated secondary amine. Besides these favorable polar key interactions, the novel semicarbazide ligands nevertheless demonstrate that high subtype selectivities for the D4 subtype over D2 and D3 can also be achieved by compounds fully occupying the EBP of D4 (Figure 4, left).

    Discussion and Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In summary, it has been shown that 1-arylpiperazines that are linked to a novel 1-benzyl-1-phenylsemicarbazide motif can display high affinity and subtype selectivity toward the dopamine D4 receptor in combination with a significant bias toward G protein activation. Taking advantage of a recently developed Barbier-type reaction, which is applicable for the reductive alkylation of phenylazocarboxamides, a series of 34 new semicarbazide ligands could be prepared via a straightforward synthetic sequence. The resulting compounds were subsequently evaluated in competition binding assays toward the three subtypes of the D2 family, and structure–activity relationships as summarized in Figure 7 were observed.
    According to docking studies, the favorable binding profile of the most promising ligand APH199 (17) [Ki(D4.4) = 0.25 nM, D2L/D4.4 = 320, D3/D4.4 = 710] results from two main factors. First, a comparably strong fixation of the ligand in the D4 receptor is likely to be achieved via a salt bridge linking the protonated piperazine to Asp115 combined with a hydrogen bond between Thr434 and the carbonyl oxygen of the novel semicarbazide substructure. Second, the particular combination of a phenyl and benzyl substituent on the semicarbazide unit leads to a full occupation of the EBP and, because of an insufficient flexibility of the 1-benzyl-1-phenylsemicarbazide in the subtypes D2 and D3, also to a clash with the bulkier side chains of Phe110 (in D2) and Phe106 (in D3), which can serve as a plausible explanation for subtype selectivity. These results demonstrate that the full occupation of the EBP in the dopamine receptor subtype D4 by ligands bearing bulky lipophilic appendages can offer a valuable starting point for future developments toward G protein-biased D4-selective agonists, which has so far not been exploited. To date, little is known about G protein-biased D4-selective agonists besides the recently published ligand 621433134 (3) (Figure 1) and the semicarbazides developed within this work. Within the D2 receptor family, most examples for biased ligands have so far been reported for the D2 subtype.(65) For research groups interested in the pharmacology of the newly developed semicarbazide ligands, we would be happy to provide samples within a future collaboration.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Synthesis

    Solvents and reagents are obtained from commercial sources and used as received. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra are recorded on Bruker AVANCE 600 (1H: 600 MHz; 13C: 151 MHz) and Bruker AVANCE 400 (1H: 400 MHz; 13C: 101 MHz) spectrometers. For 1H NMR spectra, CDCl3 is used as solvent referenced to TMS (0 ppm): CHCl3 (7.26 ppm), (CD3)2SO (2.5 ppm), CD3OD (3.31 ppm). Chemical shifts are reported in parts per million (ppm). Coupling constants are in hertz (Hz). The following abbreviations are used for the description of signals: s (singlet), d (doublet), t (triplet), q (quartet), m (multiplet), br s (broad singlet). 13C NMR (DEPTQ) spectra are recorded in CDCl3 using CDCl3 (77.16 ppm) and in (CD3)2SO using (CD3)2SO (39.52 ppm) as standard, respectively. Chemical shifts are given in parts per million (ppm). Mass spectra are recorded using electron spray ionization (ESI) and atomospheric pressure photoionization (APPI) and a sector field mass analyzer for HRMS measurements. Analytical TLC is carried out on Merck silica gel plates using short wave (254 nm) UV light to visualize components. Silica gel (Kieselgel 60, 40–63 mm, Merck) is used for flash column chromatography. Infrared spectra were recorded on a JASCO FT/IR-4100 spectrometer using a NaCl crystal (25 mm × 4 mm) purchased at Sigma-Aldrich. The bands were classified according to their intensity as strong (s), middle (m), and weak (w). The purity of the substances was determined using an analytical HPLC (10:90 → 100:0 methanol/water + 0.1% formic acid over 18 min, Eclipse XDB-C8; 5 μm; 4.6 × 150 mm). The purity of all target compounds 12a–c and 14–47 was determined as >95%.

    Synthesis and Characterization of Compounds

    General Procedure 1: Alkylation of Phenylpiperazine (GP 1)

    A suspension of the phenylpiperazine hydrochloride 7 (4.00 mmol, 915 mg), bromoalkylphthalimide 8 (8.00 mmol), and potassium carbonate (16.0 mmol, 2.21 g) was refluxed in dry acetone (25 mL) for 20 h. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and filtered, and the solid was washed with acetone (10 mL). The organic solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the crude product 9 was purified by flash chromatography.
    2-(2-(4-(2-Methoxyphenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethyl)isoindoline-1,3-dione (9a)
    Compound 9a was prepared from 1-(2-methoxyphenyl)piperazine-hydrochloride (7a) (4.00 mmol, 915 mg), N-(2-bromethyl)phthalimide (8a) (8.00 mmol, 2.03 g), and potassium carbonate (16.0 mmol, 2.21 g) in acetone (25 mL) according to GP 1. Purification by column chromatography (hexane/ethyl acetate = 3:1 → 2:1) gave 9a (3.11 mmol, 1.13 g, 78%) as a slightly yellow solid. Rf: 0.2 (hexane/ethyl acetate = 3:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 2.69–2.81 (m, 6H), 3.04 (m, 4H), 3.85 (s, 3H), 3.87–3.93 (m, 2H), 6.82–7.01 (m, 4H), 7.67–7.74 (m, 2H), 7.82–7.87 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (151 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 35.2 (CH2), 50.6 (2 × CH2), 53.3 (2 × CH2), 55.3 (CH3), 55.8 (CH2), 111.1 (CH), 118.2 (CH), 121.0 (CH), 122.8 (CH), 123.1 (2 × CH), 132.2 (2 × Cq), 133.8 (2 × CH), 141.3 (Cq), 152.2 (Cq), 168.3 (2 × Cq).
    2-(3-(4-(2-Methoxyphenyl)piperazin-1-yl)propyl)isoindoline-1,3-dione (9b)
    Compound 9b was prepared from 1-(2-methoxyphenyl)piperazine-hydrochloride (7a) (4.00 mmol, 915 mg), N-(2-brompropyl)phthalimide (8b) (8.00 mmol, 2.14 g), and potassium carbonate (16.0 mmol, 2.21 g) in acetone (25 mL) according to GP 1. Purification by column chromatography (hexane/ethyl acetate = 3:1) gave 9b (3.40 mmol, 1.29 g, 85%) as a slightly yellow solid. Rf: 0.2 (hexane/ethyl acetate = 3:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 1.91 (p, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 2.49 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 2.50–2.68 (m, 4H), 2.18–2.79 (m, 4H), 3.79 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 3.82 (s, 3H), 6.82 (ddd, J = 1.5 Hz, J = 8.0 Hz, J = 9.5 Hz, 2H), 6.88 (td, J = 1.5 Hz, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 6.96 (td, J = 1.5 Hz, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.67–7.71 (m, 2H), 7.82–7.85 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (151 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 25.2 (CH2), 36.7 (CH2), 50.4 (CH2), 53.3 (2 × CH2), 55.3 (CH3), 56.1 (2 × CH2), 111.1 (CH), 118.1 (CH), 120.9 (CH), 122.8 (CH), 123.1 (2 × CH), 132.3 (2 × Cq), 133.8 (2 × CH), 141.3 (Cq), 152.2 (Cq), 168.5 (2 × Cq).
    2-(4-(4-(2-Methoxyphenyl)piperazin-1-yl)butyl)isoindoline-1,3-dione (9c)
    Compound 9c was prepared from 1-(2-methoxyphenyl)piperazine-hydrochloride (7a) (4.00 mmol, 915 mg), N-(2-bromobutyl)phthalimide (8c) (8.00 mmol, 2.26 g), and potassium carbonate (16.0 mmol, 2.21 g) in acetone (25 mL) according to GP 1. Purification by column chromatography (hexane/ethyl acetate = 3:1) gave 9c (2.57 mmol, 1.01 g, 64%) as a slightly yellow solid. Rf: 0.2 (hexane/ethyl acetate = 1:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 1.60 (br s, 2H), 1.74 (td, J = 7.2 Hz, J = 14.9 Hz, 2H), 2.31–3.36 (m, 10H), 3.73 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 3.86 (s, 3H), 6.85 (dd, J = 1.2 Hz, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 6.90–6.95 (m, 2H), 6.98–7.01 (m, 1H), 7.70–7.73 (m, 2H), 7.83–7.86 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (91 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 24.2 (CH2), 26.7 (CH2), 37.9 (CH2), 50.6 (2 × CH2), 53.5 (2 × CH2), 55.4 (CH3), 58.1 (CH2), 111.2 (CH), 118.2 (CH), 121.0 (CH), 122.9 (CH), 123.2 (2 × CH), 132.2 (2 × Cq), 133.9 (2 × CH), 141.4 (Cq), 152.3 (Cq), 168.4 (2 × Cq).
    2-(3-(4-(4-Chlorophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)propyl)isoindoline-1,3-dione (9d)
    Compound 9d was prepared from 1-(4-chlorophenyl)piperazine-hydrochloride (7a) (5.00 mmol, 1.35 g), N-(2-brompropyl)phthalimide (8b) (10.0 mmol, 2.68 g), and potassium carbonate (20.0 mmol, 2.76 g) in acetone (60 mL) according to GP 1. Purification by column chromatography (methylene chloride/methanol = 50:1) gave 9d (2.85 mmol, 1.09 g, 57%) as a white solid. Rf: 0.4 (methylene chloride/methanol = 50:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 1.84 (dp, J = 7.1 Hz, J = 13.8 Hz, 2H), 2.32–2.51 (m, 6H), 2.90 (dd, J = 7.5 Hz, J = 12.6 Hz, 4H), 3.70 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 6.62–6.70 (m, 2H), 7.03–7.12 (m, 2H), 7.55–7.62 (m, 2H), 7.69–7.77 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (101 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 25.3 (CH2), 36.7 (CH2), 49.1 (2 × CH2), 53.1 (2 × CH2), 56.1 (CH2), 117.3 (2 × CH), 123.3 (2 × CH), 124.6 (Cq), 129.0 (2 × CH), 132.4 (2 × Cq), 134.0 (2 × CH), 149.9 (Cq), 168.6 (2 × Cq). The analytical data obtained is in agreement with those reported in literature.(66)
    2-(3-(4-(4-Bromophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)propyl)isoindoline-1,3-dione (9e)
    Compound 9e was prepared from 1-(4-bromophenyl)piperazine-hydrochloride (7c) (1.25 mmol, 302 mg), N-(2-bromopropyl)phthalimide (8b) (2.50 mmol, 670 mg), and potassium carbonate (5.00 mmol, 691 mg) in acetone (3.1 mL) according to GP 1. Purification by column chromatography (methylene chloride/methanol = 50:1) gave 9e (1.01 mmol, 434 mg, 81%) as a slightly yellow solid. Rf: 0.3 (chloroform/methanol = 50:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 1.91 (dp, J = 6.9 Hz, J = 13.7 Hz, 2H), 2.40–2.61 (m, 6H), 2.99 (dd, J = 7.5 Hz, J = 12.4 Hz, 4H), 3.75–3.84 (m, 2H), 6.64–6.74 (m, 2H), 7.24–7.33 (m, 2H), 7.62–7.74 (m, 2H), 7.78–7.88 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (101 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 25.2 (CH2), 36.6 (CH2), 48.8 (2 × CH2), 52.9 (2 × CH2), 56.0 (CH2), 111.6 (Cq), 117.5 (2 × CH), 123.1 (2 × CH), 131.8 (2 × CH), 132.3 (2 × Cq), 133.9 (2 × CH), 150.3 (Cq), 168.5 (2 × Cq).
    2-(3-(4-(Pyrimidin-2-yl)piperazin-1-yl)propyl)isoindoline-1,3-dione (9f)
    Compound 9f was prepared from 2-(piperazine-1-yl)pyrimidine-hydrochloride (7d) (1.42 mmol, 432 μL), N-(2-bromopropyl)phthalimide (8b) (2.84 mmol, 761 mg), and potassium carbonate (5.68 mmol, 785 mg) in acetone (9 mL) according to GP 1.     2-(2-(4-(4-Bromophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethyl)isoindoline-1,3-dione (9g)
    Compound 9g was prepared from 1-(4-bromophenyl)piperazine-hydrochloride (7c) (1.24 mmol, 300 mg), N-(2-bromoethyl)phthalimide (8a) (2.49 mmol, 670 mg), and potassium carbonate (4.98 mmol, 688 mg) in acetone (3.1 mL) according to GP 1. Purification by column chromatography (methylene chloride/methanol = 50:1) gave 9g (0.501 mmol, 208 mg, 40%) as a white solid. Rf: 0.2 (methylene chloride/methanol = 50:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 2.64–2.72 (m, 6H), 3.06–3.12 (m, 4H), 3.86 (t, J = 6.5 Hz, 2H), 6.72–6.78 (m, 2H), 7.28–7.33 (m, 2H), 7.69–7.74 (m, 2H), 7.82–7.86 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (101 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 35.3 (CH2), 48.9 (2 × CH), 52.9 (2 × CH2), 55.7 (CH2), 111.7 (Cq), 117.6 (2 × CH), 123.3 (2 × CH), 131.9 (2 × CH), 132.3 (2 × Cq), 134.0 (2 × CH), 150.4 (Cq), 168.5 (2 × Cq).
    2-(3-(4-(4-Iodophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)propyl)isoindoline-1,3-dione (9h)
    A suspension of 1-(4-iodophenyl)piperazine-hydrochloride (7e) (0.826 mmol, 268 mg) and potassium carbonate (1.65 mmol, 228 mg) in DMF (5 mL) was heated at 80 °C for 10 min. N-(2-Bromopropyl)phthalimide (8b) (0.909 mmol, 244 mg) was added to the mixture, and the reaction was stirred at the same temperature for 6 h. After cooling to room temperature, the solvent was evaporated, and the residue was partitioned between water (50 mL) and ethyl acetate (50 mL). The aqueous phase was further extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 30 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over sodium sulfate and evaporated to dryness. The product 9h (0.735 mmol, 339 mg, 48%) was obtained as a white solid by crystallization from ethyl acetate.(67)Rf: 0.5 (methylene chloride/methanol = 50:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 1.90 (p, J = 6.8 Hz, 2H), 2.48 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 2.50–2.55 (m, 4H), 2.97–3.04 (m, 4H), 3.79 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 6.58–6.64 (m, 2H), 7.44–7.50 (m, 2H), 7.69 (dd, J = 3.0 Hz, J = 5.5 Hz, 2H), 7.83 (dd, J = 3.0 Hz, J = 5.5 Hz, 2H); 13C NMR (151 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 25.2 (CH2), 36.7 (CH2), 48.6 (2 × CH2), 52.9 (2 × CH2), 56.1 (CH2), 81.4 (Cq), 118.1 (2 × CH), 123.2 (2 × CH), 132.4 (2 × Cq), 134.0 (2 × CH), 137.8 (2 × CH), 150.9 (Cq), 168.6 (2 × Cq).
    2-(2-(4-(4-Iodophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethyl)isoindoline-1,3-dione (9i)
    A suspension of 1-(4-iodophenyl)piperazine-hydrochloride (7e) (1.54 mmol, 500 mg) and potassium carbonate (3.08 mmol, 426 mg) in DMF (10 mL) was heated at 80 °C for 10 min. N-(2-Bromoethyl)phthalimide (8a) (1.69 mmol, 429 mg) was added to the mixture, and the reaction was stirred at the same temperature for 6 h. After cooling to room temperature, the solvent was evaporated, and the residue was partitioned between water (50 mL) and ethyl acetate (50 mL). The aqueous phase was further extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 30 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over sodium sulfate and evaporated to dryness. The product 9i (0.517 mmol, 246 mg, 63%) was obtained as a white solid by crystallization from ethyl acetate. Rf: 0.5 (methylene chloride/methanol = 50:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 2.61–2.76 (m, 6H), 3.04–3.16 (m, 4H), 3.87 (t, J = 6.4 Hz, 2H), 6.62–6.68 (m, 2H), 7.45–7.52 (m, 2H), 7.71 (dd, J = 3.0 Hz, J = 5.5 Hz, 2H), 7.84 (dd, J = 3.0 Hz, J = 5.5 Hz, 2H); 13C NMR (151 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 35.2 (CH2), 48.7 (CH2), 52.9 (2 × CH2), 55.7 (2 × CH2), 81.4 (Cq), 118.1 (2 × CH), 123.4 (2 × CH), 132.3 (2 × Cq), 134.0 (2 × CH), 137.9 (2 × CH), 150.9 (Cq), 168.5 (2 × Cq).

    General Procedure 2: Deprotection of the Alkylamines (GP 2)

    A solution of the phthalimide 9 (3.00 mmol, from GP 1) in ethanol (25 mL) was refluxed with hydrazine hydrate (30.0 mmol) for 1 h. Upon completion of the reaction, hydrochloric acid (5 mL, 2 M) was added, and the solution was let to come to room temperature while stirring. After removing the solvents under reduced pressure, the obtained solid was dissolved with a sodium hydroxide solution (2 M) and was extracted with dichloromethane (6 × 15 mL). The combined organic phases were washed with brine (20 mL) and dried over sodium sulfate. The drying agent was separated by filtration, and the solvents were removed under vacuum. The amine 10 could be used without further purification.
    2-(4-(2-Methoxyphenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethan-1-amine (10a)
    Compound 10a was prepared from 9a (3.11 mmol, 1.13 g, from GP 1) and hydrazine hydrate (31.1 mmol, 1.60 mL) according to GP 2. 10a (2.68 mmol, 631 mg, 86%) is obtained as a pure colorless oil. Rf: 0.2 (hexane/ethyl acetate = 3:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (600 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ (ppm) 2.37 (t, J = 6.5 Hz,2H), 2.50–2.56 (m, 4H), 2.68 (t, J = 6.5 Hz, 2H), 2.87–3.06 (m, 4H), 3.76 (s, 3H), 6.84–6.88 (m, 2H), 6.90–6.95 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (151 MHz, (CD3)2SO): δ (ppm) 38.2 (CH2), 50.1 (2 × CH2), 53.1 (2 × CH2), 55.3 (CH3), 60.1 (CH2), 111.9 (CH), 117.9 (CH), 120.83 (CH), 122.3 (CH), 141.3 (Cq), 152.0 (Cq). The analytical data obtained are in agreement with those reported in literature.(68)
    3-(4-(2-Methoxyphenyl)piperazin-1-yl)propan-1-amine (10b)
    Compound 10c was prepared from 9b (3.40 mmol, 1.29 g, from GP 1) and hydrazine hydrate (34.0 mmol, 1.80 mL) according to GP 2. 10b (3.00 mmol, 750 mg, 88%) is obtained as a pure colorless oil. Rf: 0.2 (hexane/ethyl acetate = 3:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 1.58 (br s, 2H), 1.64–1.74 (m, 2H), 2.44–2.52 (m, 2H), 2.59–2.74 (m, 4H), 2.79 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 2H), 3.10 (br s, 4H), 3.86 (s, 3H), 6.86 (dd, J = 1.3 Hz, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 6.90–6.96 (m, 2H), 6.97–7.02 (m, 1H); 13C NMR (151 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 30.4 (CH2), 40.9 (CH2), 50.7 (2 × CH2), 53.5 (2 × CH2), 56.6 (CH3), 56.6 (CH2), 111.1 (CH), 118.2 (CH), 121.0 (CH), 122.9 (CH), 141.3 (Cq), 152.2 (Cq). The analytical data obtained are in agreement with those reported in literature.(69)
    4-(4-(2-Methoxyphenyl)piperazin-1-yl)butan-1-amine (10c)
    Compound 10c was prepared from 9c (2.57 mmol, 1.01 g, from GP 1) and hydrazine hydrate (25.7 mmol, 1.30 mL) according to GP 2. 10c (1.68 mmol, 443 mg, 65%) is obtained as a pure colorless oil. Rf: 0.2 (hexane/ethyl acetate = 3:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD): δ (ppm) 1.46–1.63 (m, 4H), 2.42–2.45 (m, 2H), 2.60–2.76 (m, 6H), 3.06 (br s, 4H), 3.85 (s, 3H), 6.87–7.03 (m, 4H); 13C NMR (91 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 24.3 (CH2), 31.4 (CH2) 41.9 (CH2), 50.6 (2 × CH2), 53.4 (2 × CH2), 55.3 (CH3), 58.5 (CH2), 111.1 (CH), 118.2 (CH), 121.0 (CH), 122.9 (CH), 141.3 (Cq), 152.2 (Cq). The analytical data obtained are in agreement with those reported in literature.(52)

    Synthesis of Phenylazocarboxylates 11a–f

    tert-Butyl-2-(4-fluorophenyl)azocarboxylate (11a),(70)tert-butyl-2-phenylazocarboxylate (11b),(71)tert-butyl-2-(4-chlorophenyl)azocarboxylate (11c),(72)tert-butyl-2-(2,4-dichlorophenyl) azocarboxylate (11d),(70) and tert-butyl-2-(4-bromophenyl)azocarboxylate (11e)(70) were prepared as previously reported. tert-Butyl-2-(4-methoxyphenyl)azocarboxylate (11f) was prepared according to the known procedure,(70) but has not yet been reported. tert-Butyl-2-(4-methoxyphenyl)azocarboxylate (11f).(73)1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.91–7.95 (m, 2H), 6.97–7.01 (m, 2H), 3.90 (s, 3H), 1.66 (s, 9H); 13C NMR (151 MHz, CDCl3): δ 164.3 (Cq), 161.3 (Cq), 146.1 (Cq), 126.3 (2 × CH), 114.5 (2 × CH), 84.5 (Cq), 55.7 (CH3), 28.0 (3 × CH3); HRMS (EI): calcd for C12H16N2O3 [M]+, 236.1161; found, 236.1163.

    General Procedure 3: Synthesis of Phenylazocarboxamides 12 (GP 3)

    The phenylazocarboxylate 11 (2.20 mmol), the amine 10 (2.00 mmol, from GP 2), and potassium carbonate (8.00 mmol) were dissolved in dry ethanol (4.5 mL) in a flame-dried Schlenk flask under an argon atmosphere. The mixture was stirred at 40 °C, and the reaction course was monitored by TLC. Once the reaction was completed, water (5 mL) was added, and the product was extracted with ethyl acetate (3 × 15 mL). The combined organic phases were washed with brine (2 × 10 mL) and dried over sodium sulfate. The drying agent was separated by filtration, and the solvents were removed under vacuum. The crude product 12 was purified by flash chromatography or recrystallized from hot ethyl acetate.
    2-(4-Fluorophenyl)-N-(2-(4-(2-methoxyphenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethyl)diazene-1-carboxamide (12a)
    Compound 12a was prepared from 4-fluorophenylazocarboxylate 11a (2.93 mmol, 657 mg) and 10a (2.68 mmol, 636 mg, from GP 2) according to GP 3. Recrystallization from hot ethyl acetate 100% gave 12a (2.56 mmol, 985 mg, 96%) as an orange solid. Rf: 0.3 (ethyl acetate = 100%) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 2.63–2.89 (m, 6H), 3.02–3.30 (m, 4H), 3.61–3.70 (m, 2H), 3.87 (s, 3H), 6.84–7.04 (m, 4H), 7.21 (dd, JHF = 8.1 Hz, JHF = 9.0 Hz, 2H), 8.01 (dd, JHF = 5.2 Hz, JHF = 9.0 Hz, 2H); 13C NMR (91 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 37.1 (CH2), 50.5 (2 × CH2), 53.2 (2 × CH2), 55.4 (CH3), 56.5 (CH2), 111.3 (CH), 116.5 (d, JCF = 23.1 Hz, 2 × CH), 118.2 (CH), 121.0 (CH), 123.1 (CH), 126.4 (d, JCF = 9.5 Hz, 2 × CH), 141.0 (Cq), 147.8 (d, JCF = 3.1 Hz, Cq), 152.3 (Cq), 160.5 (Cq), 166.0 (JCF = 256.1 Hz, Cq); HPLC: 254 nm, tr (min) = 15.5 min, purity: 96%.
    2-(4-Fluorophenyl)-N-(3-(4-(2-methoxyphenyl)piperazin-1-yl)propyl)diazene-1-carboxamide (12b)
    Compound 12b was prepared from 4-fluorophenylazocarboxylate 11a (3.30 mmol, 740 mg) and 10b (3.00 mmol, 750 mg, from GP 2) according to GP 3. Recrystallization from hot ethyl acetate 100% gave 12b (1.93 mmol, 774 mg, 65%) as an orange solid.     N-(2-(4-(4-Bromophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethyl)-2-phenyldiazene-1-carboxamide (12l)
    Compound 12l was prepared from the phenylazocarboxylate 11b (1.78 mmol, 367 mg, 5 equiv) and 10g (0.356 mmol, 101 mg, from GP 2) according to GP 3. In contrast to GP 3, 5 equivalents of 11b were needed to get comparable yields. Purification by column chromatography (methylene chloride/methanol = 20:1) gave 12l (0.301 mmol, 139 mg, 85%) as an orange solid.     N-(3-(4-(4-Iodophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)propyl)-2-phenyldiazene-1-carboxamide (12m)
    Compound 12m was prepared from the phenylazocarboxylate 11b (2.16 mmol, 446 mg, 5 equiv) and 10h (0.432 mmol, 149 mg, from GP 2) according to GP 3. In contrast to GP 3, 5 equivalents of 11b were necessary. Also, ethyl acetate (3 mL) was needed here instead of ethanol because of low solubility of 10h. Purification by column chromatography (hexane/ethyl acetate = 1:15 + 3% NH3) gave 12m (0.105 mmol, 50.3 mg, 24%) as an orange solid. Rf: 0.3 (hexane/ethyl acetate = 1:15 + 3% NH3) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 1.84–1.99 (m, 2H), 2.63–2.77 (m, 6H), 3.14–3.27 (m, 4H), 3.65 (dd, J = 5.6 Hz, J = 11.7 Hz, 2H), 6.60–6.66 (m, 2H), 7.38 (dd, J = 6.1 Hz, J = 13.6 Hz, 2H), 7.48–7.57 (m, 3H), 7.83–7.89 (m, 2H), 8.29 (br s, 1NH); 13C NMR (101 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 24.8 (2 × CH2), 41.0 (CH2), 48.8 (CH2), 52.9 (2 × CH2), 57.6 (CH2), 118.4 (2 × CH), 123.9 (2 × CH), 129.4 (2 × CH), 133.6 (CH), 138.0 (2 × CH), 151.2 (Cq), 161.0 (Cq). Two Cq signals are missing because of the signal noise ratio.
    N-(2-(4-(4-Iodophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethyl)-2-phenyldiazene-1-carboxamide (12n)
    Compound 12n was prepared from the phenylazocarboxylate 11b (4.48 mmol, 924 mg, 5 equiv) and 10i (0.897 mmol, 297 mg, from GP 2) according to GP 3. In contrast to GP 3, 5 equivalents of 11b were necessary. Also, ethyl acetate (4.5 mL) was needed here instead of ethanol because of low solubility of 10i. Purification by column chromatography (hexane/ethyl acetate = 1:15 + 3% NH3) gave 12n (0.359 mmol, 166 mg, 40%) as an orange solid. Rf: 0.5 (hexane/ethyl acetate + 3% NH3 = 1:15) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 2.67–2.82 (m, 6H), 3.20–3.27 (m, 4H), 3.61–3.73 (m, 2H), 6.66–6.72 (m, 2H), 7.11 (br s, 1NH), 7.49–7.62 (m, 5H), 7.93–7.98 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (151 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 37.1 (CH2), 48.6 (2 × CH2), 52.8 (2 × CH2), 56.6 (CH2), 81.9 (Cq), 118.3 (2 × CH), 124.1 (2 × CH), 129.4 (2 × CH), 133.7 (CH), 138.0 (2 × CH), 150.7 (Cq), 151.3 (Cq), 160.9 (Cq).

    General Procedure 4: Reductive N-alkylation of Phenylazocarboxamides (GP 4)

    To a solution of the phenylcarboxamide 12 (0.15 mmol, from GP 3) and benzyl (or allyl) bromide 13 (0.375–0.750 mmol) in tetrahydrofuran (2.0 mL), a saturated aqueous solution of ammonium chloride (0.5 mL) and zinc powder (0.375–1.50 mmol) was added under vigorous stirring. After completion of the reaction, as monitored by TLC, and decoloration of the mixture, water and hydrochloric acid (1.0 mL, 1 M) were added, and the aqueous phase was washed with diethyl ether (3 × 10 mL). Subsequently, a solution of sodium hydroxide (4.0 mL, 1 M) was added to the aqueous phase, which was then extracted with dichloromethane (4 × 10 mL). The combined organic phases were washed with brine (10 mL) and dried over sodium sulfate. The drying agent was separated by filtration, and the solvents were removed under vacuum. The crude product was purified by flash chromatography and additionally by preparative HPLC, when needed.
    2-Benzyl-2-(4-fluorophenyl)-N-(2-(4-(2-methoxyphenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethyl)hydrazine-1-carboxamide (14)
    Compound 14 was prepared from 2-(4-fluorophenyl)-N-(2-(4-(2-methoxyphenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethyl)azocarboxamide 12a (130 μmol, 50.0 mg) and benzyl bromide (13a) (325 μmol, 39.0 μL) according to GP 4. Purification by column chromatography (dichloromethane/ethyl acetate = 1:1) gave 14 (94.0 μmol, 44.9 mg, 72%) as a colorless oil. Rf: 0.1 (methylene chloride/ethyl acetate = 1:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 2.39–2.85 (m, 6H), 2.87–3.19 (m, 4H), 3.19–3.47 (m, 2H), 3.86 (s, 3H), 4.38–4.75 (m, 2H), 5.99 (br s, 1NH), 6.33 (br s, 1NH), 6.83–7.06 (m, 8H), 7.20–7.35 (m, 5H); 13C NMR (91 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 36.1 (CH2), 50.2 (2 × CH2), 53.0 (2 × CH2), 55.3 (CH3), 56.9 (CH2), 59.7 (CH2), 111.2 (CH), 115.9 (d, JCF = 22.5 Hz, 2 × CH), 116.8 (d, JCF = 7.7 Hz, 2 × CH), 118.2 (CH), 121.0 (CH), 123.1 (CH), 128.0 (CH), 128.6 (2 × CH), 128.7 (2 × CH), 135.2 (Cq), 140.9 (Cq), 145.6 (d, JCF = 2.4 Hz, Cq), 152.2 (Cq), 158.0 (d, JCF = 240.6 Hz, Cq), 158.0 (Cq); HRMS (ESI): calcd for C27H33FN5O2 [M + H+], 478.2613; found, 478.2606; HPLC: 254 nm, tr (min) = 18.0 min, purity: 98%.

    2-([1,1′-Biphenyl]-4-ylmethyl)-2-(4-fluorophenyl)-N-(3-(4-(2-methoxyphenyl)piperazin-1-yl)propyl)hydrazine-1-carboxamide (24)
    Compound 24 was prepared from 2-(4-fluorophenyl)-N-(2-(4-(2-methoxyphenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethyl)azocarboxamide (12b) (100 μmol, 40.0 mg) and 4-(bromomethyl)-1,1′-biphenyl (13g) (300 μmol, 74.1 mg) according to GP 4.     2-Benzyl-N-(2-(4-(4-bromophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethyl)-2-phenylhydrazine-1-carboxamide (45)
    Compound 45 was prepared from N-(2-(4-(4-bromophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethyl)-2-phenyldiazene-1-carboxamide (12l) (168 μmol, 70.0 mg) and benzyl bromide (13a) (840 μmol, 99.3 μL) according to GP 4. Purification by column chromatography (methylene chloride/methanol = 17:1) gave 45 (30.0 μmol, 15.5 mg, 18%) as a yellow oil. Rf: 0.4 (methylene chloride/methanol = 17:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 2.36–2.63 (m, 6H), 2.90–3.11 (m, 4H), 3.24–3.38 (m, 2H), 4.53 (d, J = 15.0 Hz, 1H), 4.70 (d, J = 15.0 Hz, 1H), 6.05 (br s, 1NH), 6.12 (br s, 1NH), 6.70–6.76 (m, 2H), 6.91–6.97 (m, 1H), 7.00–7.05 (m, 2H), 7.22–7.30 (m, 7H), 7.32–7.36 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (101 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 36.4 (CH2), 48.9 (2 × CH2), 52.7 (2 × CH2), 56.9 (CH2), 58.8 (CH2), 112.1 (Cq), 114.9 (2 × CH), 117.8 (2 × CH), 121.4 (CH), 128.0 (CH), 128.6 (2 × CH), 128.9 (2 × CH), 129.5 (2 × CH), 132.0 (2 × CH), 135.7 (Cq), 149.3 (Cq), 150.2 (Cq), 158.2 (Cq); HRMS (APPI): calcd for C26H31BrN5O [M + H]+, 508.1706; found, 508.1711; IR (NaCl) ν (cm–1): 2942 (m), 2823 (m), 2239 (w), 1671 (s), 1494 (s), 1234 (s), 1150 (m), 911 (m), 811 (m), 733 (s); HPLC: 254 nm, tr (min) = 17.7 min, purity: 98%.
    2-Benzyl-N-(3-(4-(4-iodophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)propyl)-2-phenylhydrazine-1-carboxamide (46)
    Compound 46 was prepared from N-(3-(4-(4-iodophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)propyl)-2-phenyldiazene-1-carboxamide (12m) (158 μmol, 75.4 mg) and benzyl bromide (13a) (790 μmol, 93.8 μL) according to GP 4. Purification by column chromatography (methylene chloride/methanol = 10:1) gave 46 (54.4 μmol, 31.0 mg, 34%) as a slightly yellow oil. An analytical sample was purified using preparative HPLC (5:95 → 95:5 acetonitrile/water + 0.1% formic acid over 18 min, flow rate: 10 mL/min, ZORBAX Eclipse XDB-C8) to yield the desired product 46. Rf: 0.5 (methylene chloride/methanol = 10:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 1.62–1.74 (m, 2H), 2.48 (dd, J = 6.4 Hz, J = 12.2 Hz, 2H), 2.59–2.71 (m, 4H), 3.00–3.36 (m, 6H), 4.51 (d, J = 14.8 Hz, 1H), 4.67 (d, J = 14.8 Hz, 1H), 6.14 (br s, 1NH), 6.29 (br s, 1NH), 6.55–6.67 (m, 2H), 6.92 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 1H), 7.02 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.20–7.35 (m, 7H), 7.48–7.58 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (101 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 26.0 (CH2), 39.2 (CH2), 48.2 (2 × CH2), 53.1 (2 × CH2), 57.0 (CH2), 58.1 (CH2), 81.7 (Cq), 114.7 (2 × CH), 118.2 (2 × CH), 121.2 (CH), 128.1 (CH), 128.9 (4 × CH), 129.6 (2 × CH), 135.2 (Cq), 137.8 (2 × CH), 149.3 (Cq), 150.6 (Cq), 158.3 (Cq); HRMS (APPI): calcd for C27H33IN5O [M + H+], 570.1724; found, 570.1729; IR (NaCl) ν (cm–1): 2927 (m), 1671 (s), 1598 (s), 1588 (s), 1531 (s), 1494 (s), 1453 (s), 1244 (m), 755 (m), 697 (m); HPLC: 254 nm, tr (min) = 17.3 min, purity: 100%.
    2-Benzyl-N-(2-(4-(4-iodophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethyl)-2-phenylhydrazine-1-carboxamide (47)
    Compound 47 was prepared from N-(2-(4-(4-iodophenyl)piperazin-1-yl)ethyl)-2-phenyldiazene-1-carboxamide (12n) (151 μmol, 70.0 mg) and benzyl bromide (13a) (755 μmol, 89.6 μL) according to GP 4. Purification by column chromatography (methylene chloride/methanol = 15:1 → 10:1) gave 47 (58.3 μmol, 32.4 mg, 39%) as a yellow oil. An analytical sample was purified using preparative HPLC (5:95 → 95:5 acetonitrile/water + 0.1% formic acid over 18 min, flow rate: 10 mL/min, ZORBAX Eclipse XDB-C8) to yield the desired product 47. Rf: 0.4 (methylene chloride/methanol = 10:1) [UV]; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 2.44 (dd, J = 5.8, 9.6 Hz, 2H), 2.49–2.61 (m, 4H), 2.91–3.11 (m, 4H), 3.23–3.37 (m, 2H), 4.53 (d, J = 14.9 Hz, 1H), 4.68 (d, J = 14.9 Hz, 1H), 6.09–6.17 (m, 2H), 6.59–6.67 (m, 2H), 6.94 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 1H), 7.02 (d, J = 7.9 Hz, 2H), 7.19–7.37 (m, 7H), 7.46–7.56 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (101 MHz, DEPTQ, CDCl3): δ (ppm) 36.4 (CH2), 48.6 (2 × CH2), 52.6 (2 × CH2), 56.9 (CH2), 58.8 (CH2), 81.7 (Cq), 114.9 (2 × CH), 118.2 (2 × CH), 121.4 (CH), 128.0 (CH), 128.6 (2 × CH), 128.9 (2 × CH), 129.6 (2 × CH), 135.7 (Cq), 137.9 (2 × CH), 149.26 (Cq), 150.8 (Cq), 158.2 (Cq); HRMS (ESI): calcd for [M + H]+, 556.1574; found, 556.1578; IR (NaCl) ν (cm–1): 2849 (w), 2364 (w), 1676 (s), 1593 (s), 1536 (s), 1494 (s), 1453 (s), 1228 (m), 817 (m), 755 (m), 697 (m); HPLC: 254 nm, tr (min) = 18.1 min, purity: 100%.

    Receptor Binding Studies

    Radioligand binding studies with the subtypes of the D2 receptor family were performed as described previously.(74) In brief, competition binding experiments were done using membranes of CHO cells stably expressing the human D2L, D2S,(75) D3,(76) or D4.4(77) receptor. Radioligand displacement assays were run in binding buffer (25 mM HEPES, 5 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EDTA, 0.006% BSA at a pH of 7.4) with [3H]spierone (specific activity = 79 Ci/mmol, PerkinElmer, Rodgau, Germany) at final concentrations of 0.20–0.30 nM. The assays were carried out at protein concentrations of 4–6 μg/assay tube, a Bmax value of 1800 ± 120 fmol/μg, a KD value of 0.11 ± 0.026 nM for D2L, of 1 μg protein/assay tube, Bmax of 7800 ± 2100 fmol/μg, KD of 0.083 ± 0.017 nM for D2S, of 2–4 μg protein/assay tube, Bmax of 2900 ± 480 fmol/μg, KD of 0.11 ± 0.021 nM for D3, and of 6–10 μg protein/assay tube, Bmax of 1100 ± 110 fmol/μg, KD of 0.19 ± 0.024 nM for D4.4, respectively. Unspecific binding was determined in the presence of 10 μM haloperidol, and protein concentration was established by the method of Lowry using bovine serum albumin as standard.(78) Competition binding experiments with GPCRs related to D2–D4 were performed in an analogous manner with membranes from HEK293T cells transiently transfected with the corresponding cDNA by using the Mirus TransIT-293 transfection reagent (PeqLab, Erlangen, Germany) or a solution of polyethylenimine in PBS (PEI, linear 25 kDa, Polysciences, 1 mg/mL) as transfection reagent at a 3:1 PEI to cDNA ratio.(79,80) Binding to the dopamine receptors D1 and D5 was performed with the radioligand [3H]SCH23390 (60 Ci/mmol, Biotrend, Cologne, Germany) at a final concentration of 0.30 nM, KD of 0.23 nM, Bmax of 1200 fmol/mg, and 2 μg protein/well for D1, and of 0.50 nM, KD of 0.50 nM, Bmax of 1700 fmol/mg, and 6 μg protein/well for D5, respectively. Affinities to adrenergic receptors were determined applying [3H]prazosin (84 Ci/mmol, Biotrend) at 0.20 nM, KD of 0.095 nM, Bmax of 7500 fmol/mg, and 2 μg protein/well for α1A, [3H]RX821002 (57 Ci/mmol, PerkinElmer) at 0.30 nM, KD of 0.29 nM, Bmax of 900 fmol/mg, and 10 μg protein/well for α2A, [3H]CGP12177 (34 Ci/mmol, Biotrend) at 0.30 nM, KD of 0.25 nM, Bmax of 4000 fmol/mg, and 3 μg protein/well for β1, and [3H]CGP12177 (34 Ci/mmol, Biotrend) at 0.30 nM, KD of 0.060 nM, Bmax of 4000 fmol/mg, and 3 μg protein/well for β2, respectively. Opioid receptor binding was performed with the radioligand [3H]diprenorphine (31 Ci/mmol, PerkinElmer) at 0.30 nM and a KD of 0.25 nM, Bmax of 1700 fmol/mg and 8 μg protein/well for δOR, KD of 0.13 nM, Bmax of 6500 fmol/mg and 2 μg protein/well for κOR, and KD of 0.095 nM, Bmax of 4000 fmol/mg and 3 μg protein/well for μOR, respectively. Affnities to the muscarinic receptors M1, M2, and M3 were determined with [3H]NMS (80 Ci/mmol, Biotrend) at 0.30 nM and a KD of 0.12 nM, Bmax of 2500 fmol/mg, and 2 μg protein/well for M1, KD of 0.25 nM, Bmax of 500 fmol/mg, and 10 μg protein/well for M2, and a KD of 0.14 nM, Bmax of 3500 fmol/mg, and 3 μg protein/well for M3, respectively. Serotonin receptor binding was measured with [3H]WAY100635 (80 Ci/mmol, Biotrend) at 0.20 nM, KD of 0.10 nM, Bmax of 3000 fmol/mg, and 2 μg protein/well for 5-HT1A, and [3H]ketanserin (47 Ci/mmol, Biotrend) at 0.30 nM, KD of 0.17 nM, Bmax of 1400 fmol/mg and 7 μg protein/well for 5-HT1A, respectively.
    The resulting competition curves of the receptor binding experiments were analyzed by nonlinear regression using the algorithms in PRISM 6.0 (GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA). The data were initially fit using a sigmoid model to provide an IC50 value, representing the concentration corresponding to 50% of maximal inhibition. IC50 values were transformed to Ki values according to the equation of Cheng and Prusoff.(81)

    Accumulation of Inositol Monophosphate (IP-One Assay)

    Determination of the activation of the dopamine D4 receptor and the adrenergic α1A receptor was measured applying the IP-One HTRF assay (Cisbio, Codolet, France) according to the manufacturer’s protocol and as described previously.(82,83) In brief, HEK-293T cells were grown to a confluence of approx. 70% and transiently co-transfected with the cDNA of the human D4R (from the cDNA Resource Center, Bloomberg, PA) and of the hybrid G-protein Gαqi (Gαq protein with the last five amino acids at the C-terminus replaced by the corresponding sequence of Gαi; gift from The J. David Gladstone Institutes, San Francisco, CA) or transfected with α1AR (cDNA Resource Center, Bloomberg, PA) applying the Mirus TransIT-293 transfection reagent (PeqLab, Erlangen, Germany). After 1 day, cells were detached from the culture dish with Versene (Life Technologies, Darmstadt, Germany), seeded into black 384-well plates (10 000 cells/well) (Greiner Bio-One, Frickenhausen, Germany), and maintained for 24 h at 37 °C. Agonist properties were determined by incubating the test compounds (final range of concentration from 1 pM up to 10 μM) in duplicates for 90 min (D4R) or 60 min (α1AR) at 37 °C. Incubation was stopped by addition of the detection reagents (IP1-d2 conjugate and anti-IP1cryptate TB conjugate each dissolved in lysis buffer) for further 60 min at room temperature. Time-resolved fluorescence resonance energy transfer (HTRF) was measured using the Clariostar plate reader (BMG, Ortenberg, Germany).

    Arrestin Recruitment Assay (PathHunter Assay)

    Determination of β-arrestin-2 recruitment was performed applying the PathHunter assay (DiscoverX, Birmingham, U.K.) which is based on fragment complementation of β-galactosidase in HEK293 cells stably expressing (EA)-β-arrestin-2 and being transiently transfected with a receptor tagged to the PKA fragment as described.(82,84) Cells were transfected with the D4-PKA or the ADRA1A-PK construct employing Mirus TransIT-293 (PeqLab, Erlangen, Germany) and incubated in DMEM/F12 medium (Life Technologies, Darmstadt, Germany) at 37 °C and 5% of CO2. After 24 h, cells were detached with Versene (Life Technologies) and transferred into 384-well plates (white plate, transparent bottom, Greiner Bio-One, Frickenhausen, Germany) at a density of 5000 cells/well using the medium CP7 Reagent (DiscoverX). After further 24 h of incubation, test compounds at concentrations from 10 pM to 100 μM dissolved in PBS were added to the cells at a final volume of 25 μL and incubated at 37 °C for 6 h. Antagonist properties at the D4R were determined by preincubation of the cells with the test compound (from 10 nM to 30 μM) for 30 min followed by addition of 300 nM quinpirole (EC80) and continuation of incubation for further 6 h. Determination of β-arrestin-2 recruitment was started by adding detection mix, incubation at room temperature for 60 min, and measuring chemoluminescence with a Clariostar plate reader (BMG, Ortenberg, Germany).

    Data Analysis of Functional Experiments

    Data analysis of functional experiments was performed by normalizing the raw data relative to basal activity (0%) and the maximum effect of the reference agonist quinpirole (100%). Normalized curves from six individual experiments each done as duplicate were analyzed by nonlinear regression applying the algorithms in Prism 6.0 (GraphPad, San Diego, CA) to get dose–response curves representing average EC50 and Emax value.

    Operational Model of Agonism

    Quantification of ligand bias was performed using the operational model by Black and Leff.(54) The calculations were carried out according to recently published protocols (see the Supporting Information for details).(55,56)

    Metabolism Studies

    Metabolism experiments were performed as described previously in the publication by Hiller et al.(58) Pooled microsomes of the male rat liver (Sprague-Dawley) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and stored at −75 °C. NADPH was purchased from Carl and Roth and stored at −8 °C. The incubation reactions were performed in polyethylene caps (Eppendorf 1.5 mL) at 37 °C. The incubation mixture contained APH199 (17) (20 μM) or imipramine (20 μM), used as positive control, pooled rat liver microsomes (0.5 mg of microsomal protein/mL of incubation mixture), and Tris-MgCl2 buffer (50 mM Tris and 5.0 mM MgCl2, pH 7.4). The final incubation volume was 0.5 mL. Microsomal reactions were started by adding 50 μL of enzyme cofactor solution NADPH (final concentration of 1 mM). After predetermined times of 0, 15, 30, 60, and 120 min, 100 μL samples were drawn from the incubation mixture and the reactions were terminated by adding 100 μL of ice-cold acetonitrile (containing internal standard 28; final concentration of 25 μM). After removing precipitated proteins by centrifugation (15 000 rpm, 3 min), the supernatant was analyzed by HPLC/MS (binary solvent system, eluent methanol in 0.1% aqueous formic acid, 10–90% methanol in 15 min, 90% methanol for 4 min, 90–10% in 2 min). All incubations were performed in duplicate. Parallel control experiments were performed in the absence of cofactor NADPH solution to determine unspecific binding to matrix and in the absence of APH199 (17) or imipramine, respectively.

    Molecular Docking Studies

    All ligands for molecular modeling were built using the programs Avogadro (version 1.2.0)(59) and AutoDockTools (version 1.5.6).(60) The ligands were protonated at the secondary amine group to receive the protonation state under the physiological pH value. The geometry of each ligand was optimized by energy minimization. For the docking studies, the crystal structures of the human dopamine D2, D3, and D4 receptors were used in complex with antagonists risperidone (PDB: 6CM4), eticlopride (PDB: 3PBL), and nemonapride (PDB: 5WIU), respectively. The related PDB files were downloaded from the RCSB PDB webpage.(47,62,63) Docking was performed using AutoDock Vina(61) while a search space of 20 × 20 × 20 Å was applied to cover the whole binding pocket, which was defined by the appropriate crystal ligand for each receptor sub type. In order to validate our methods, we reproduced the binding poses of risperidone, eticloprid, and nemonapride in the D2, D3, and the D4 receptor, respectively. An exhaustiveness value of 8 was used with randomly selected starting positions. For each ligand, 20 conformations were received and analyzed manually. Considering the scoring function of AutoDock Vina and the presence of the salt bridge to Asp 1153.32 (D4 receptor), one plausible conformation was selected for each receptor ligand complex. Visualization of the receptor ligand complexes was accomplished with the PyMOL Molecular Graphics System, Version 1.3 (Schrödinger, LLC).

    PAINS Screening

    SMILES codes were determined for all target compounds using ChemDraw 16.0 (PerkinElmer), and screening for pan assay interference and aggregation liability was performed using the tools and standard filters(85) implemented in the ZINC 15 database.(86) The screening (see Supporting Information) resulted in no detectable PAINS patterns for all semicarbazides 14–47 and led to warnings for 12a–c because of the azo substructure incorporated in these ligands.

    References

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    This article references 86 other publications.

    1. 1
      Vallone, D.; Picetti, R.; Borrelli, E. Structure and function of dopamine receptors. Neurosci. Biobehav. Rev. 2000, 24, 125– 132,  DOI: 10.1016/s0149-7634(99)00063-9
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Structure and function of dopamine receptors
      Vallone, D.; Picetti, R.; Borrelli, E.
      Neuroscience and Biobehavioral Reviews (2000), 24 (1), 125-132CODEN: NBREDE; ISSN:0149-7634. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
      This review with 87 refs. focuses on the pharmacol. and biochem. features shared by the dopamine receptors. Dopamine (DA) is the most abundant catecholamine in the brain. The involvement and importance of DA as a neurotransmitter in the regulation of different physiol. functions in the central nervous system (CNS) is well known. Deregulation of the dopaminergic system was linked with Parkinson's disease, Tourette's syndrome, schizophrenia, attention deficit hyperactive disorder (ADHD), and generation of pituitary tumors. The authors address their coupling to secondary messenger pathways and their physiol. function based upon studies using pharmacol. tools, specific brain lesions and, more recently, genetically modified animal models.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXjtVylug%253D%253D&md5=0fa459e1055a9542eebfc06834ad7a72
    2. 2
      Missale, C.; Nash, S. R.; Robinson, S. W.; Jaber, M.; Caron, M. G. Dopamine receptors: from structure to function. Physiol. Rev. 1998, 78, 189– 225,  DOI: 10.1152/physrev.1998.78.1.189
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Dopamine receptors: from structure to function
      Missale, Cristina; Nash, S. Russel; Robinson, Susan W.; Jaber, Mohamed; Caron, Marc G.
      Physiological Reviews (1998), 78 (1), 189-225CODEN: PHREA7; ISSN:0031-9333. (American Physiological Society)
      A review, with 481 refs. The diverse physiol. actions of dopamine are mediated by at least five distinct G protein-coupled receptor subtypes. Two D1-like receptor subtypes (D1 and D5) couple to the G protein Gs and activate adenylyl cyclase. The other receptor subtypes belong to the D2-like subfamily (D2, D3, and D4) and are prototypic of G protein-coupled receptors that inhibit adenylyl cyclase and activate K+ channels. The genes for the D1 and D5 receptors are intron-less, but pseudogenes of the D5 exist. The D2 and D3 receptors vary in certain tissues and species as a result of alternative splicing, and the human D4 receptor gene exhibits extensive polymorphic variation. In the central nervous system, dopamine receptors are widely expressed because they are involved in the control of locomotion, cognition, emotion, and affect as well as neuroendocrine secretion. In the periphery, dopamine receptors are present more prominently in kidney, vasculature, and pituitary, where they affect mainly sodium homeostasis, vascular tone, and hormone secretion. Numerous genetic linkage anal. studies have failed so far to reveal unequivocal evidence for the involvement of one of these receptors in the etiol. of various central nervous system disorders. However, targeted deletion of several of these dopamine receptor genes in mice should provide valuable information about their physiol. functions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXptlOjtg%253D%253D&md5=a505d0e2c640ca205d4470ad69f607ff
    3. 3
      Beaulieu, J.-M.; Gainetdinov, R. R. The physiology, signaling, and pharmacology of dopamine receptors. Pharmacol. Rev. 2011, 63, 182– 217,  DOI: 10.1124/pr.110.002642
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      The physiology, signaling, and pharmacology of dopamine receptors
      Beaulieu, Jean-Martin; Gainetdinov, Raul R.
      Pharmacological Reviews (2011), 63 (1), 182-217CODEN: PAREAQ; ISSN:0031-6997. (American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics)
      A review. G protein-coupled dopamine receptors (D1, D2, D3, D4, and D5) mediate all of the physiol. functions of the catecholaminergic neurotransmitter dopamine, ranging from voluntary movement and reward to hormonal regulation and hypertension. Pharmacol. agents targeting dopaminergic neurotransmission have been clin. used in the management of several neurol. and psychiatric disorders, including Parkinson's disease, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, Huntington's disease, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD1), and Tourette's syndrome. Numerous advances have occurred in understanding the general structural, biochem., and functional properties of dopamine receptors that have led to the development of multiple pharmacol. active compds. that directly target dopamine receptors, such as antiparkinson drugs and antipsychotics. Recent progress in understanding the complex biol. of dopamine receptor-related signal transduction mechanisms has revealed that, in addn. to their primary action on cAMP-mediated signaling, dopamine receptors can act through diverse signaling mechanisms that involve alternative G protein coupling or through G protein-independent mechanisms via interactions with ion channels or proteins that are characteristically implicated in receptor desensitization, such as β-arrestins. One of the future directions in managing dopamine-related pathol. conditions may involve a transition from the approaches that directly affect receptor function to a precise targeting of postreceptor intracellular signaling modalities either directly or through ligand-biased signaling pharmacol. In this comprehensive review, we discuss dopamine receptor classification, their basic structural and genetic organization, their distribution and functions in the brain and the periphery, and their regulation and signal transduction mechanisms. In addn., we discuss the abnormalities of dopamine receptor expression, function, and signaling that are documented in human disorders and the current pharmacol. and emerging trends in the development of novel therapeutic agents that act at dopamine receptors and/or on related signaling events.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXjslGis70%253D&md5=53e6841062c98abe60c732692109e498
    4. 4
      Löber, S.; Hübner, H.; Tschammer, N.; Gmeiner, P. Recent advances in the search for D3- and D4-selective drugs: probes, models and candidates. Trends Pharmacol. Sci. 2011, 32, 148– 157,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tips.2010.12.003
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Recent advances in the search for D3- and D4-selective drugs: probes, models and candidates
      Lober Stefan; Hubner Harald; Tschammer Nuska; Gmeiner Peter
      Trends in pharmacological sciences (2011), 32 (3), 148-57 ISSN:.
      Dopamine D(2)-like receptors (including D(2), D(3) and D(4)) belong to the 'rhodopsin-like' family of G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), which represent the largest group of targets for bioactive molecules. Due to their high sequence similarity, the design of subtype-selective ligands requires rational and effective strategies. The general formula of 1,4-disubstituted aromatic piperidines and piperazines (1,4-DAPs) was extracted from classical dopaminergic drugs. The biological properties of this compound family are encoded by an aromatic head group that controls intrinsic activity, an amine moiety and a lipophilic appendage. D(3)- and D(4)-selective molecular probes and drug candidates were generated from the general formula of 1,4-DAP. Formal structural rearrangement led to investigational drugs beyond the 1,4-DAP structure. The very recent publication of the X-ray crystal structure of D(3) should facilitate efficient discovery of unprecedented chemotypes. However, the development of D(3)-selective agonists, functionally selective ligands and the exploitation of homo- and heteromers remain challenging.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3M3ktVWnsg%253D%253D&md5=9b688525eaa75c6d965b634617c16d70
